Dasenbrock ~ and D. Lubach ~ Tetrachlorodibenzo-p-dioxin (TCDD) was administered topically on the inner ear skin surface and the tail skin of female C57BL/6J-mice. Administered to 6 mice per group, the dosages of TCDDD which was dissolved in acetone were 0, 0.01, 0.1, 1, 5 and 10 nmol/0.25 cm ~ skin. The animals were sacrified three days later by cervical dislocation. Tail and ear skin were dissected. The epidermis was separated from the remaining tissue by dispase incubation. The incorporation rate of thymidine triphosphate into DNA and of leucine and histidine into protein were measured. Additionally, keratin proteins were separated by polyacrylamide gel electrophoresis. TCDD induced a dose-dependent increase of the thymidine triphosphate incorporation rate in tail and ear epidermis. An enhanced leucine incorporation was found also in both regions, while the histidine incorporation increased only in the ear epidermis. In contrast to ear epidermis, a dose-dependent increase of the intensity of keratin protein fractions in the molecular range of 45 to 70 kDa was found in the tail epidermis. Similar changes were found also after repeated oral administration of TCDD (Kietzmann, M. et al., Naunyn Schmiedeberg's Arch. Pharmacol. 344 (Suppl.) , R113, 1991) . From these results it is suggested that the determination of epidermal metabolic parameters is a sensitive tool to demonstrate effects of chlorinated hydrocarbons. We have shown that arsenic inhibits glucose uptake in Madin-Darby canine kidney (MDCK) cells (1). In addition to the known impairment of cellular energy metabolism, this inhibition may contribute to the acute toxicity, especially of trivalent organic arsenicals, like oxophenylarsine (PhAsO). We have now investigated whether the inhibited glucose uptake may be reversed by 2,3-dimercaptopropanol (BAL) and other sulfhydryl reagents. The culture medium (DMEM/F12) of confluent MDCK cells (3-4 d) was repIaced by Hanks's buffered salt solution containing 10 ~moI/I glucose. 30 rain later 2 Ixmol/1 PhAsO, and again 30 rain later 2, 20 or 200 ~tmol/] of various thiol compounds were added. At timepoims 5, 10, 20, 30, 40, 60, 90, 150, 180 min after arsenic addition an uptake assay with [6-t4C]-glucose was performed as described (1). In the preseuce of PhAsO glucose uptake was reduced to about 50 % of the controls within 30 rain. This inhibition could be reversed in a time-and concentration dependent manner when BAL or related dithiol compounds, e.g. 2,3-dimercaptopropanesulfonate (DMPS) and meso-2,3-dimercaptosuccinic acid (DMSA) were added after 30 rain. The water-soluble dithiols DMPS and DMSA required higher concentrations / 1ouger incubation times for complete reversal of the As-induced inhibition. On the other hand, monotbiols, e.g. 2-mercaptoethanol, could not restore impaired glucose uptake. It is concluded that 1) inhibited glucose uptake in MDCK ceils is reversed by antidotes which also effectively antagonize the metabolic effects of arsenic and that 2) MDCK cells may provide a valuable experimental system for the investigation of potential arsenic antidotes. In rats, dietary arsenic leads to a concentration-and timedependent accumulation of copper exclusively in the kindney, preferentially in the cortex. Compared to controls with renal copper levels of about 5 ug Cu/g wet wt, feeding of a diet with 60 ~g As/g of diet (as NaAsOs) for 2 wk increased renal copper levels to about 45 Dg Cu/g wet wt. D~e to the high retention of arsenic in the erythrocytes, the rat is considered to have a special metabolism of arsenic which could have been responsible for the observed effect. Therefore, we looked for a corresponding effect of dietary arsenic in mice and guinea pigs. Each species was divided into 4 groups of animals according to the diets fed which contained increasing concentrations of NaAsOs (0, i0, 30 and 60 pg As/g of diet). Animals were killed by exsanguination after feeding periods of I, 2 and 3 wk. The liver, kidneys and small intestine were removed and analysed for arsenic and other trace metals (Cu, Fe and Mn) by atomic emisssion spectrometry. An increase of renal copper levels by increased dietary arsenic concentration, to an extent similar to that in rats, was only observed in guinea pigs which, however, did not accumulate arsenic in the blood. Renal copper accumulation was time and concentration dependent as in rats. Feeding a diet with 60 ,g As/g for 3 wk increased renal copper level from about 5.5 to 40 ~g Cu/g wet wt.

The study shows that the renal copper-arsenic interaction is not restricted to the rat and is not due to a high blood retention of arsenic. Since in rats and guinea pigs, but not in mice, arsenic accumulated in the kidney to a much higher extent than in other organs, it is suggested that copper and arsenic accumulate synchronously. Using a series of effectors we were able to exclude free hydroxyl radicals and superoxide. The use of a singlet ox?fgen trap in combination with HPLC allowed us also to eliminate singlet oxygen as an alternative light emitting species. Our results strongl~ support that the light emission stems from an electron transter to the berne-bound hydrogen peroxide via a globin peptide. Therby a protein radical and the ferryl tbrm of heine were formed. This was concluded by EPR spectroscopy in combination with visible spectroscopy. A tentative reaction mechanism is discussed.

The consequences of oxidative stress were investigated in normal and glutathione-<leplated rat hepatocytes. Glutathione(GSH)-depletfon was achieved by way of GSH-reductase inhibition (75 pM BCNU) or GSHconjugation with phorone (250 pM). Oxidative stress was subsequently induced by incubating the cells in an atmosphere of humidified air with 500 pM nitrefurantoin (NFT). Under these conditions NFT enters a redox-cycle which generates toxic reactive oxygen species. When cytoprotection was hampered due to the lack of GSH, NFT was highly detrimental as demonstrated by trypan blue exclusion, lactate dehydmgenase leakage, decrease of the intracallular K+-concentration, plasma membrane blebbing, lipid perexipation and loss of reduced protein thiol groups. However, the sensitivity of BCNU-pretreated cells, which still disposed of reduced GSH in the early phase of NFT-exposure, was much higher compared to pharone=pretreeted cells raising the question whether GSH might be partly involved in the cytotoxic process. The importance of GSH and protein dedved thief groups was strengthened by the fact that thiol reducing agents (i,e, dithiothreitol) as well as GSH precursors (i.e. N-acetyl-cysteice) diminished or postponed cellular injury, A protective effect could be achieved even after prolonged incubation when most of the cells already exhibited extensive plasma membrane biebbing. This indicates the promising use of certain thiol-reactive substances in the defense of oxidative stress. Since thiol homeostasis is believed to interfere with the cellular Ca ++compartmentation cytosolic free Ca++-concentrations were measured and compared with the degree of cytotoxicity. Ca++-alterations are supposed to tdgger cell damage, thus antagonists of Ca ++ -activated processes were investigated with regard to their cytoprotective potential. FU Berlin, Koserstr. 20 There is only restricted information about transfer of mercury from the mother to the fetus. We have compared mercury concentrations in maternal blood vs. umbilical blood and placenta. 186 women (16-42 years) from South Germany (Ulm area) and their newborns were included in the study. Possible sources of exposure to mercury (fish consumption, occupation, etc.) and health status were assessed by questionnaire. Amalgam status was quantified by dental inspection. Blood samples were taken in K-EDTA tubes. The samples were digested with nitric acid in the Perkin-Etmer Autoclave-3 under pressure and at increased temperature. The determination of total mercury concentration was carried out by Cold Vapor AAS (Perkin-Elmer Atomic Absorption Spectrophotometer A.AS 430, MHS-20). The median values for mercury concentrations were for maternal blood 0.63 (0.1-7 3) tag/t, for umbilical blood 0.78 (0. I-5.0) gg/t and for placenta 4.09 (0.71-25.0) tag/kg ~vet weight. Number of amalgams ranged between 0-18 (mean 7.3) and surface area between 0-770 mm 2 (mean 278.3). The women with amalgams (n=166) had, on average, higher level of mercury in blood 0.66 (0.1-7.3) lag/1 than the women (n=20) without amalgams 0.39 (0.1-1.6) gg/L Though mercury concentrations are only moderate correlated with the number and surface of amalgams. The results demonstrate that mercury concentrations in fetal blood exceed those in maternal blood and that dental amalgams of the mother contribute to the mercury exposure of the fetus. Inhalative zinc chloride poisoning is a rare, but life-threatening calamity seen after short-time exposure to zinc chloride smoke. An effective therapy is not established and lethality is high. Acute respiratory distress syndrome (ARDS) is the most prominent clinical feature of this intoxication and death from respiratory insufficiency usally ensues several days later. In order to establish an in-vitro model to investigate acute toxic effects of zinc salts we have studied several cell lines derived from human lung. The cancer cell line A549, and fibroblast-like 8Lu, 11Lu and 16Lu cells were grown in DMEM/F12 medium supplemented with fetal calf serum (10% vlv) at 37°C in moist atmosphere containing 5% CO2. After reaching confluency the cells were exposed to various concentrations of zinc chloride. Cell viability and morphology were assessed and angiotensin-converting enzyme (ACE) activity was measured as a biochemical parameter. When Zn concentrations exceeded 100 gmol/1 the growth of the cultures was progressively depressed. The formation of blebs and the detachment from substratum were indicators of impaired cellular viability. In Lu cells ACE activity increased and showed a maximum after 16 h exposure to zinc. No ACE activity could be detected in A549 cells. When corticosteroids (< 10 ~tmol/l of hydrocortisone, beclomethasone, budesonide) were administered prior to the addition of zinc no prophylactic effect could be observed. ACE activity increase and cell death were similar in treated cultures and in controls (without steroids). On the other hand, known antidotes against heavy metal intoxication like 2,3-dimercaptopropanesuffonate, Dpenicillamine, and 2,3-dimercaptopropanol (BAL) effectively prevented zincrelated toxic effects including the ACE activity rise when given in 10fold molar excess over zinc. Our data suggest that fibroblast-like Lu cells provide a suitable in vitro model for the study of zinc-related toxic effects and the evaluation of prophylactic measures. Hepatic Cu-levels are elevated in the newborn and dramatically change during development. Cu in the particulate fraction of neonatal liver has been reported to be partly localized in lysosomes. This Cu has been assumed to be bound to aggregated metallothionein (MT).

The aim of the present study was to estimate the accumulation and distribution of Cu, Zn and MT in isolated hepatic lysosomes of neonatal male Wistar rats of various ages. Lysosomal fractions were obtained by differential centrifugation followed by isopycnic centrifugation in Percoll ® gradients. Lysosomal fractions were identified by activity of acid phosphatase and separated into light and heavy fractions according to density. Cu and Zn were quantified by AAS or ICP-AES. Zn-and Cu-containing MT was analyzed by the Thiomolybdate(1)-assay. The amount of oxidized MT was determined after treating the samples with 2-mercaptoethanol. Whereas Zn was detected in both, the light and heavy lysosomal fractions, Cu was almost exclusively found in heavy tysosomes. Cu and MT levels in heavy lysosomes were high during the first 13 days of life and showed a characteristic decline thereafter. MT, however, was almost totally oxidized suggesting its inability to bind metals. Therefore, MT seems not to represent the major Cu-binding protein in lysosomes of neonatal rat liver.

(1)Anal. Biochem. 189, 35-39 (1990) * The transepithelial electrical resistance (TER) has been used to assess the functional integrity of epithelia. Madin-Darby canine kidney (MDCK) cells are well-known for their cell polarity when grown in culture. For example, virus budding has been shown usually to occur from the apical membrane face for many viruses, but from the basolateral domain for Vesicular Stomatitis Virus (Rodriguez-Boulain et al., J. Cell Biol. 96 (1983) 866-874) . We have studied the effect of zinc, cadmium and mercury added to the apical or basolateral side of MDCK cell cultures on the time course of TER. Wild-type MDCK cells were grown on permeable supports in DMEM/F12 medium at 37°C in moist atmosphere containing 5% CO2. Cells developed TER values above 2000 ~cm 2 within 2 -3 days after reaching confluency. The addition of zinc, cadmium and mercury acetates on both sides of the monolayer led to a concentration-dependent TER decrease within 24 h. The decrease in TER was followed by detachment of the cells from the support and other signs of impaired cellular viability. Equipotent concentrations for almost complete abolition of TER within 24 h were 10 pmol/1 HgAc2, 50 gmol/l CdAc2 and 500 gmol/1 ZnAc2. When the metal salts were added on one side of the monolayer zinc (500 txmolft) decreased the TER only when given to the basolateral face. Cadmium was also more effective when added to the basolareral compartment. However, mercury.salts completely abolished the TER when added to either side. The series of increasing toxicity in the order Zn < Cd < Hg was paralleled by a decreasing membrane domain selectivity. Our data suggest that the inherent polarity of cultured MDCK cells might also play an important role in the cytotoxicity of heavy metals. It is tentatively assumed that the observed polarity corresponds to an asymmetric distribution of cellular targets responsible for the binding of the heavy metal ions. (b.w.: 200 g) . The animals (6 per group) were sacrificed under diethyl ether narcosis 0.5; 1.0; 2.0; 3.0; 6.0; 12,0 hrs after Au applic.. Zinc (Zn), copper (Cu) and Au were measured by atomic absorption spectrometry, and the metallothionein content was determined by gel chromatography.
The main purpose of this study was to find out, whether the induction of metallothionein synthesis is caused by Au itself or by intracellular mobilization of Zn or Cu by Au.

I. As first event an accumulation of Au was observed in the kidney already 0.5 hrs after Au applic.. 2.) This event was followed by a delayed increase of Cu and metallothionein concentrations 6 hrs after Au applic.. 3.) The Zn content in the kidney did not change significantly during the observation period of 12 hrs.

These results indicate that the first event is an increase of Au concentration in kidney cytosol. The second step seems to be an induction of metallothionein production by Au, which is followed by an increase of Cu binding to this metallothionein.

In the last years, metallothionein (MT) became of increasing interest not only for the investigation of heavy metal toxicology but also for studies on tumor resistance to anticancer drugs, especially C/splatin and its analogues. However many investigations are limited, since MT quantification is rather difficult. Often the 2°JHg-binding assay and the Cd/hemoglobine affinity assay are used which are relatively unspecific and do not allow differentiation between various isoproteins of MT. Therefore two chromatographic methods are presented and compared, allowing an exact chemical quantification of different MT-isoproteins. Commercially available MT from rabbit liver was used as reference substance and sample preparation was done by solid phase extraction with RP-18 cartridges. First a conventional HPLC-analysis was performed using an acetonitril/water-gradient. Separation of MT-isoproteins from rabbit liver requires a 80 rain. run with a detection limit of 2/~g/ml MT. Secondly, MT analysis was done by capillary zone electrophoresis using a phosphatebuffer-system of pH 2,5 containing methylcellulose to reduce electroosmotie flow. Complete separation of MT-isoproteins was achieved after 20 min with a detection limit of 0,2 /zg/ml MT. For the future, capillary eleetrophoresis seems to be an appropriate method to achieve a fast and high resolving quantification of MT-isoproteins. Learning disorders and changes in behaviour have frequently been observed in children and in experimental animals as the result of chronic exposure to lead. The molecular causes of these neuretoxic effects are still largely unexplained. Damage to central receptor systems is assumed. As the NMDA (N-Methyl-D-Aspartate)receptor, a subtype of the glutamate receptor, is probably involved in cognitive functions in the CNS, our investigations were intended to clarify to what extent this type of receptor in the brains of mice was influenced by lead in vitro and in vivo. The investigations were carried out on adult and juvenile NMRI raice. Female mice were given 100 or 1000 ppm lead as nitrate in their drinking water tbr 30 and 90 days. The water was available ad libitum. Juvenile animals were exposed pre-and posmatally by providing pregnant mice from the 5th post conception day with 100 or 1000 ppm lead in their drinking water. Characterisation of the NMDA-receptors was carried out ex rive using binding studies on homogenates from the frontal cortex of the brain with the allosteric NMDA antagonist 3H-MK-801. In vitro, complete inhibition of the radioligand binding was found with an ICs0 value of 19.7 -+ 2.6 ~M (SEM). In comparison, the lead content in frontal cortex of juvenile mice treated with 1000 ppm lead was determined to be 10.0 +-. 1.8/.~mol/kg W.W. (SEM). In the presence of amino acids and of divalent cations, such as calcium or magnesium, low lead concentrations led to a significant increase in receptor affinity. Analysis of the saturation experiments, which were carried out on brain homogenates of lead-treated animals, showed a slight increase in receptor density of 13 or 15% with an unchanged KD value only in the adult animals treated with 100 ppm lead. If radioligand binding was stimulated with glycine and glutamate, this effect could no longer be observed. No changes in receptor affinity or receptor density were found in the neonatal lead exposed juvenile animals. Modulation of radioligand binding by lead, which was demonstrated in vitro, is not associated in the same manner with changes in receptors in the in vivo lead-exposed animals. In summary it can be said that on the basis of the in rive findings obtained in our experiments on mice, the neurotoxic effects of lead are not attributable to impairment of cortical NMDA receptors.

body_text.text: C a d m i u m adversely affects the energy metabolism and thereby impairs the calcium homeostasis. To clarify the effectfi of Cd 2 + on myocardial cells we measured the intracellular free Ca z + concenIration over a longer period by means of fura 2. The influence of Cd z + was monitored during the systolic and diastolic phases of isolated cells of an adult guinea-pig heart. The tiara loaded cells were placed in a temperature controlled (35 ° C) chamber (0.5 ml volume) on a Zeiss IM 35 fluorescence microscope. The chamber was perfused with 0 2 saturated modified Krebs Hense-]eit Buffer (KHB; 1.2 m M Ca2+; 1 m l / m i n ) with or without CdC12. The fluorescence of one cell was selected with an adjustable rectangular diaphragm. The A m k o muttiscan-2-fluorimeter was used for excitation and data aquisition. _The ratio of 340/380 nm excitation represents the free intracellular Ca z + . After addition of 5 ~M Cd 2+ at 0.5 Hz stimulation frequency, we found a decrease of the ratio by 49% during 40 s. Thereafter only a slight further decrease of the calciumtransient but a m a r k e d increase of the diastolic Ca 2+ concentration has been observed. After 5 rain the cell was superfused with KHB without Cd 2 + . Then the transient increased but the Ca 2+ concentration during the diastole remained ~onstant~ These effects were als9 seen to a smaller extent at 1 ~M Cd 2+ . These results show that Cd 2+ has two effects on the free intracellular [Ca 2 + ]i" The first is a calciumantagonistic effect at the outside of the membrane. It corresponds to the results of Lansman et al. (J. Gen. Physiol., 88, 321-347, 1986) . They reported about blocking of the Ca current through single calcium channels in guinea-pig ventricular cells by Cd 2+ . The second may be an intracellular effect which leads to an increase of [Ca 2 + ]i in the diastolic phase. Further investigations are necessary to elucidate the latter effect. In order to correlate the radical formation with the exerted cytotoxic effects the extent of membrane damage, the thiol and energy status, lipid peroxidation, membrane blebbing and disturbance of intracellutar calcium homeostasis were determined. Alterations in intracellular free calcium are supposed to be an important trigger of the cascade of pathobiochemical reactions in radical induced cell death. Nevertheless a correlation between the quantity of lipid peroxidation and call damage in general with changes in intracellular free calcium, as indicated by the fluodmetdc determination with Quin-2-AM could not be found in all cases. BrCI3C and CumOOH induced a rise in intrecellular calcium whereas the other substances used did not. On the other hand deterioration of call viability was supreme in AA treated calls. This marked discrepancy leads to the conclusion that cytosolic free calcium oscillations are not the pivotal triggering impulse in radical induced call death. Oximes are used in organophosphate (OP) poisoning to restore neuromuscular block (NMB). Because of lacking efficacy in some types of poisoning and inherent toxicity the therapeutic effect of obidoxime chloride (OBI), pralidoxime iodide (2-pAM) and the newer oximes HI 6 (l-(((4-(aminocarbonyl)pyridinio)methoxy) methyl)-2-(hydroxyim/no)methyl)pyridinium dichloride) and HL5 7 (l-(((4-(aminocarbonyl)pyridinio) methcxy) methyl)-2,4-bis((hydroxyim/no) methyl) pyridinium dimethanesulfonate) on paraoxon induced NMB of the mouse phrenic nerve-diaphragma was investigated in vitro. In a continuously perfused bath, muscles were stimulated indirectly in 30 sec intervals with 20 Hz (T20), 50 Hz (T50) and i00 Hz (T100) for 2 sec. The generated force within the stimulation period was measured (results as percent of control): firstly for control (100%); secondly for OP effect after a 25 minute incubation period with paraoxon (0.01 mmol/l), followed by wash out of the ~oison after NMB was achieved; thirdly for oxime effect estimation after a further 15 minute incubation period with different oximes (0.5 mmol/l, each; n = 6/group). Type XIII AChE (Sigma, St. Louis) was inhibited by paraoxon or monocrotophos for 30 minutes at pH 7,4 and 37,0°C and then reactivated by HL6 7, HI 6, obidoxime or pralidoxime (i0 ~mol/l, each) for 60 minutes.

RI8, 1989 ) the combined application of dexamethasone and activated charcoal markedly reduces lethality in acute poisoning with T-2 toxin (3~-OH-4B,15-diacetoxy-8~-(3-methyl-butyryloxy)-12,13-epoxy-trichothec-9-en) a trichothecene mycotoxin. We investigated wether the treatment alters the amount of metabolites excreted or the metabolite pattern. Tritium labelled T-2 toxin (0.66 mg/kg) was injected into the tail vein of 12 male Sprague Dawley rats. After 30 min., three rats each received activated charcoal (i g/kg, po; group II) or dexamethasone (8 mg/kg, iv; group III) or the combination of both (group IV) or only the vehicle (group I). T-2 toxin and its metabolites in urine and feces were determined by HPLC and LC-MS. During the experimental period of 50 hours, less than 1% of the administered dose appeared as unchanged T-2 toxin. In the urine, 2-4% of the administered dose was present as deacetylated T-2 toxin (HT-2), and about 10% as 3'OH HT-2 in all experimental groups. In the feces, 3'OH HT-2 was the main metabolite, (15% of the administered dose in group I and 20% in group II-IV) followed by 3'OH T-2 (1.2-2.8%). In minute amounts only (<1%) HT-2 was detected in group I-III, nothing in group IV. Furthermore, in group I less than 0.5% of the dose was found as HT-2 glucuronide, whereas in group IV about 4.5% was found as HT-2 glucuronide. It is concluded that the treatment with dexamethasone and charcoal did not alter markedly the elimination pattern of T-2 toxin and its metabolites. Chem. 251 289 (1970) . Silicosis is a progressive fibrotic lung disease caused by inhalation of silica (SiO2) particles. There is suggestive evidence that, given a comparable dust exposure, genetic factors decide on whether silicosis develops or not. For investigation of this different genetic predisposition to fibrotic reaction a mouse model was developed with Balb/c as high-responder and DBA/2 as Iow-responder strains. Silica particles are taken up by macrophages and presumably enhance the production by these cells of fibrogenic cytokines, such as IL-11?,, TNF~,, and TGF-fL if true, genetic differences in susceptibility to silicosis should be reflected in a different cytokine pattern long before formation of pathological alterations. To test this hypothesis Balb/c and DBA/2 mice were injected i.p. with 0.Stag SiO 2 or, for control, the inert dust TiO 2, Using PCR, mRNA expression by peritoneal cells of the IL-lf$, TNFc¢, IL-6, and TGFf~ 1 was determined after 5,8,11,14 and 17 days, respectively. One group of both strains remained untreated. Following injection of SiO 2 and TiO 2, respectively, non-responder DBA/2 mice failed to show mRNA expression of TNFo,, TGFI~I, and IL-6. IL-1I~ was expressed constitutively, but dust treatment failed to enhance expression of this cytokine. In the highresponder Balb/c, IL-I£; mRNA expression showed a strong increase after exposure to both TiO 2 and SiO 2 ( days 11, 14, 17). TNFe¢ expression was enhanced in SiO2-treated mice (days 11, 14, 17) compared with the TiO2-treated and the untreated groups. As in DBA/2 mice, TGFI~ 1 expression was undetectable. Similar to IL-11~, expression of IL-6, an inflammatory but not a fibrogenic cytokine, was elevated in both TiO 2-and SiO 2-treated Balb/c mice. These genetic differences in SiO 2-induced cytokine expression are consistent with the results of previous studies showing an essential role of TNFct in the pathogenesis of silicosis. Furthermore, this animal model may be used as a test system for antifibrotic and anti-inflammatory drugs. Several members of polycyclic aromatic hydrocarbons (PAH) containing the structural element of a "fjord-region", e.g. the pentacyclic benzo[c]chrysene (BcCh) and benzo[g]chrysene (BgCh) and the hexacyclic dibenzo[a,l]pyrene (DBalP), exhibit mutagenic and carcinogenic properties. In particular the environmental pollutant DBa/P is the strongest carcinogenic PAH ever tested.

In addition, investigations on the DNA-binding in vitro of the "fjord-region" dihydrodiol epoxides of DBa/P by the P-32 postlabeling method exhibited multiple nucleobase adducts thus showing a remarkable and polyregional affinity of these electrophilic molecules to DNA.

Dibenz[,~,h]anthracene (DBA) exhibits two bay-regions at distal sites of the molecule. Many polycyclic aromatic hydrocarbons bearing a bayregion are metabolized by P-450 enzymes into possible DNA binding diol epoxides, Also from DBA bay region diol epoxide-DNA adducts were found after metabolic activation and the absolute stereochemistry of these adducts was assigned. Furthermore highly polar DNA adducts were obtained. These polar DNA adducts were also formed from /razz.ca'arzg-3,4; 10, ll-tetrahydroxy-3,4; 10,11 -tetrahydro-DBA (DBA-3,4;10,11bisdiol) as well as from a,'at~,s-3,4-dihydroxy-3,4-dihydro-DBA (DBA-3,4-diol) after incubation with calf thymus DNA in presence of liver microsomes form rats treated with Aroclor 1254. Due to the symmetry of the molecule only three enantiomers of DBA-3,4;10,11-bisdiol are conceivable. Highly polar DNA adducts were only observed for metabolites of those DBA-3,4;10,11-bisdiols, 3A',4A';10A',llA'-tetrahydroxy-3,4;10,11-tetrahydro-DBA and 3A',4A';10S,11,.¢-tetrahydroxy-3,4;10,11-tetrahydro-DBA, having at least one R,A'-configurated dihydrodiol moiety. No DNA adducts which could be assigned to metabolites of 3~,4d'; I 0~,11S-tetrahydroxy-3,4; 10,11-tetrahydro-DBA were found. These findings were congruent with the observation that bay-region diol epoxide-DNA adducts were predominently formed from a metabolite of the h',A~-configurated enantiomer of DBA-3,4-diol after incubation of DBA with DNA in presence of the metabolizing system. Because of this similar stereoselectivity it is probable that the same isoenzyme which is responsible for the further biotransformation of DBA-3,4-diol to the diol epoxide is also responsible for activation of 4; 10, We have developed an assay in which specific repair endonucleases (formamidopyrimidine-DNA glycosylase, endonudease III, exonudease ]II) are used to quantify various oxidative modifications (8-hydroxyguanine, 5,6-dihydropyrimidines, sites of base loss) in mt-DNA. The assay makes use of the fact that an incision by repair endonucleases at modified DNA sites gives rise to a relaxation of the supercoiled mt-DNA molecule that can be easily detected and quantified. The mt-DNA was isolated from mitochondria of rat and porcine liver and kidney by a mild lysis protocol; supercoiled DNA from bacteriophage PM2 was added before lysis and served as internal control for damage during the workup procedure. The results indicate that the mt-DNA of the animals contained less than one 8-hydroxyguanine residue per 105 base pairs. No base modifications sensitive to endonuclease III (5,6-dihydropyrimidines) could be detected. It has to be concluded that the steady-state level of oxidative modifications in mt-DNA of young healthy animals is low. Chloroprene (2-chloro-1,3-butadiene) is used for the production of chemical resistant plastics and glues. The substance has not been classified by the IARC (International Agency for Research on Cancer) in regard to its carcinogenic potential. Since the chemically closely related substances 1,3-butadiene and vinyl chloride are proven carcinogens, and previous data on chloroprene are inconsistent, experiments were performed to investigate the mutagenicity of chloroprene. Pure chloroprene is unstable. It was purchased from Matthey Co., FRG, as a 50% solution in xylene and freshly distilled prior to each experiment. Due to the low boiling point of chloroprene, the Ames Test with S. typhitnurium TA100 was performed as a preincubation test in gas tight screw cap vials. Propylene oxide served as positive control. Cytotoxicity and mutagenicity were investigated in parallel experiments. Freshly distilled chloroprene was not mutagenic, neither as solution in ethanol, nor in DMSO, nor with the addition of $9 mix. However a mutagenic effect occured with increasing age of the distilled substance. The mutagenicity of aged chloroprene was the same whether it was tested under gas tight conditions or not, it doubled when $9 mix was added. Glutathione, in physiological concentrations, reduced the mutagenic and cytotoxic effects, both with and without metabolic activation. Analysis by gas chromatography revealed six substances, which were not found in freshly distilled chloroprene.The mutagenicity of aged chloroprene correlates linearily with the appearance of four of these substances. Under pure oxygen, the increase of these byproducts was faster than in samples kept under air. Under argon, two new substances are formed, which were also found to be mutagenic in the Ames Test.The formation of these substances was slow at -20°C and rapid at room temperature Analysis by GC/MS revealed the presence of peroxides and dimers in chluroprene kept under aerobic conditions, and the presence of dimers in samples kept under argon.

body_text.text: Electrostatic interactions between histones and poly(ADPribosyl)conjugates are involved in nucleosomal unfolding of chromatin required for DNA repair, DNA replication and initiation of gene transcription. Thus poly(ADP-ribosyl)ation, which is induced by DNA strand breaks, may be an important link between DNA damage, alteration of gene expression and malignant transformation. The present study investigates the induction of poly(ADP-ribosyl)ation by three renal carcinogens with different mechanisms of action. Dichlorovinylcysteine, the metabo~ite responsible for the nephrotoxic and nephrocarcinogenic effects of trichloroethene, is a potent inducer of Cag+-dependent DNA double strand breaks; application of dichlorovinylcysteine to male Wistar rats in vivo results in a dose-and time-dependent increase in the amount of poly(ADPribosyl)conjugates in the rat kidney cortex. A similar increase was observed with KBrO3, whose nephrotoxicity and nephrocarcinogenicity is probably resulting from increased formation of reactive oxygen species. Administration of a single dose of dimethylnitrosamine to rats, maintained on protein-free diet, has been shown to induce kidney tumors in absence of gross nephrotoxicity. However, the identical exposure regimen did not influence the poly(ADP-ribosyl)transferase activity in the renal cortex nuclei from treated rats. The results indicate that poly(ADP-ribosyl)ation may be an important aspect of the organ specific effect for nephrocardnogens that mainly act by inducing mediated DNA damage.

The possible role of araehidonic acid metabolism in the tumor-promoting activities of TCDD and TCB was studied i~n vitrq. (i) TCDD and TCB enhanced the DMS0-induced differentiation of the erythroleukemia cell line F4-6, as measured as an increase of the cellular hemoglobin content. This effect was significantly reduced by indomethacin, an inhibitor of cyclooxygenase, or dexamethasone, an inhibitor of phospholipase A 2. (2) TCDD enhanced the malignant transformation of M2 mouse fibroblasts induced by Nmethyl-N'-nltro-N-nltrosoguanidine or 3-methylcholanthrene. This effect was abolished by the addition of either indomethacln or hydrocortisone. Furthermore, M2 flbroblasts were labelled with 3H-araehidonic acid and, thereafter, the calcium ionophore (A23187)-stimulated release of radioactivity into the culture medium was measured. This release was enhanced after TCDD-or TCBtreatment of these cells. Thus, the results suggest that the metabolism of arachldonic acid is increased by TCDD or TCB and that metabolites of the aracidonic acid may be involved in the tumor-promoting activities of TCDD or TCB i~n yitro, !-~., the enhancement of differentiation and of cell transformation. and chemically-induced severe liver injury. It has been suggested that these cells can give rise to cholangiocellular as well as hepatocellular carcinomas. In order to test this hypothesis established oval cell lines were transformed in vitro either by leaving the cells for long time periods in confluence or by exposing the cells to N-nitro-N'-nitro-N-nitrosoguanidine and injected s.c. in newborn rats. The obtained tumors were poorly to well differentiated cholangiocellular carcinomas, being solid, cysticpapillary and glandular in structure; no areas of hepatocytic differentiation were visible. Whereas the tumors were albumin-, alpha-fetoprotein-and ferritin--negative, they stained positive for cytokeratins 7, 8, 18 and 19. In an attempt to analyze the plasticity of the cultured oval cells these were exposed to dimethyl sulfoxide (DMSO) or sodium butyrate (SB), two differentiation promoting agents, for up to 6 days and the expression of a number of bile duct epithelial and parenchymal cell markers was studied. After addition of DMSO or SB 35-40% of the cells reexpressed albumin, glucose-6-phosphatase activity was enhanced and tyrosine aminotransferase activity remained undetectable; furthermore, SB strongly increased gamma-glutamyltranspeptidase and alkaline phosphatase activities. In conclusion, the results presented herein show that: i) oval cells are the precursor cells of cholangiocellular carcinomas; 2) certain traits of mature liver parenchymal cells can be rexpressed in oval cells after exposure to DMSO or SB; however, taking into account the morphology of the cells before and after treatment with DMSO or SB one cannot conclude that these substances are supporting a general program of hepatocyte differentiation in oval cells. With polyfunctional compounds, several adducts can be formed, and their analysis provides information about major and minor metabolic activation pathways, which may be used to assess the metabolic status of the individual. We administered single doses of 1,3-diaminobenzene (1,3DAB), l-amino-3-nitrobenzene (IA3NB) and 1,3dinitrobenzene (I,3DNB) to female Wistar rats, isolated hemoglobin after 24 h, determined the hydrolysable adducts and calculated a hemoglobin binding index (HBI = Binding (ntmol/mol Hb)/Dose (mmol/kg)). At least two cleavage products were obtained by hydrolysis of the sulfinamide type adduct. The high HBI of 1,3DNB corresponds well with the known capacity of met-Hb formation. It is concluded that (i) nitrogroups in 1,3DNB are to some extent reduced to the amine , but l-nitroso-3-nitrobenzene is predominantly bioavailable, Ethylene oxide (EO), a proven carcinogen in animals, is a major plastic monomer and a sterilizing agent for heat sensitive materials. Due to its chemical reactivity, it is able to react directly with nucleophilic sites in proteins and nucleic acids. During the past years, some research has been done on the determination of these adducts in animals and humans. Both have been discussed as possible parameters for a biological monitoring of exposed workers and linear dose-adduct relationships have been investigated. In a previous study, we determined DNA adducts both in lymphocytes of unexposed rats (base levels) and in liver of rats exposed to unlabelled EO. Furthermore, Potter et al. [1] determined the relationship between the alkyladon of DNA of various tissues (and hemoglobin) using 14C-labelled EO. On the basis of these results, however, a comparison ofadduct levels between exposed and unexposed animals is not possible. Male Sprague Dawley rats (5 animals per dose) were exposed in a closed exposure chamber (10.3 1) to 0, 30, 60, and 125 gmol 14C-labelled EO. In addition, 5 animals received 460 gmol unlabelled EO in a similar exposure system. The EO concentration was monitored by GC and the exposure was terminated at a final concentration lower than 1 ppm. The animals were sacrificed andliver and spleen were extracted from each animalJ Lymphocytes were isolated from all animal blood sample. DNA was prepared from these samples, hydrolysed in 0.1 N HC1, and 7-(2-hydroxyethyl)-guanine levels were determined by HPLC in the case of the labelled compound and by GC/MS in the case of unlabelled EO. Prior to the determination, the GC/MSsamples were silylated by N-methyl-N-trimethylsilyltrifluoroacetamide. The investigation of labelled 7-(2-hydroxyethyl)-guanine shows a linear dose-dependency that is comparable to the results of Potter et al. [1] . The amount of this guanine adduct is approximately 20 % of the whole total activity bound to liver DNA. The results allow a comparison with the results from lymphocyte and liver DNA previously investigated.

body_text.text: [1] Potter et al.: Arch. Toxicol. Suppl.: 13, 254-257 (1989 Methyl bromide (MBr) is widely used as a fumigant because of its fungicide, nematocide, and insecticide properties. Since the substance has a high acute toxicity and a systemic genotoxic potential in laboratory animals, monitoring of human exposureto MBris necessary. This monitoring cannot be performed by the measurement of the concentration of the substance in ambient air or by its quantitation in blood or urine due to interindividual differences in metabolism. Prelimin ary in vitro experiments showed that an enzyme polymorphism for GSH conjugation in erythrocytes influences the individual uptake and distribution of MBr in human blood. A determination of the biological effective dose by measurement of alkylation adducts with blood macromolecules may therefore be better suited for biological monitoring. On the basis of these in vitro experiments, a method was established for the parallel quantitation of serum albumin and globin adducts as biomonitoring parameters. First, the proteins were isolated from whole human blood. After acid hydrolysis (6 N HCI, 1100 C, 24 h), amino acids were de rivatized with FMOC, yielding fluoresce nt adducts. In the next step, HPLC amino acid analysis was performed using a RP 8 column, a binary gradient system, and a fluorescence detector. Levels of S-methylcysteine were determined in both proteins. Compared to unexposed controls, significantly higher levels of cysteine adducts were measured in both albumin and globin of MBr workers. Additionally, the importance of the enzyme polymorphism was outlined. As a result, the method presented here is suitable forthe biomonitodng of MBr-workers and shows a good comparison between the common target proteins in human blood. , one of the carcinogenic heterocyclic arylamines found in fried meat, fish and meat extract, is metabolically activated to DNA-binding arylnitrenium ions by N-oxidation and a subsequent acetylation. Using cell cultures we have recently shown that human N-acetyltransferases (NAT1 and NAT2) contribute to the activation and DNAbinding of IQ and probably have an associated O-acetyltransferase (OAT) activity (Probst et al., Carcinogenesis 13, 1713 ft., 1992 . Here we report experiments performed to test a correlation of N-acetyltransferase (NAT) activity in different organs of rats and the occurrence of IQ-DNA-adducts. Two rat strains (F344, WKY) were used. NAT activities with the substrates sulfamethazine (SMZ), p-aminobenzoic acid (PABA) and IQ were determined in cytosols from liver, lung, pancreas, and intestine. After a single oral dose of IQ (30 mg/kg) IQ-DNAadducts were assayed by means of 32p-postlabelling. The PABA-NAT activities in liver and other organs were 3-5 times higher in F344 than in WKY rats. Thus the F344 rats are rapid and the WKY rats slow acetylators. However, the SMZ-NAT activities differed only slightly and the IQ-NAT activities were identical in the two strains. Of all organs, the intestine had the highest PABA-NAT activity (5-10 times more than liver); liver generally had the highest SMZ-NAT and IQ-NAT activities, in F344 rats, liver had also most IQ-DNA-adducts (304 adducts/108 bases); the adduct frequencies correlated with the IQ-NAT activities in all organs (r2=0,9) . Adduct studies with WKY rats are in progress. The above data show that the level of genotoxicity of IQ depends on the acetylator status. This is probably relevant also for human slow versus rapid acetylators.

In addition to ct-C-hydroxylation and subsequent bioactivation, carcinogenic N-nitroso compounds are also denitrosated by a Cyt. P-450 dependent reaction. NO is generated by this pathway and it is converted to NO2" and NO3" by the intermediary formation of NO2. It should be mentioned that NO is also generated via the L-arginine pathway as a 2nd messenger in different mammalian cells. Previously we could show that gaseous NO: was able to induce DNA single strand breaks (SSBs) in Chinese hamster lung (V 79) fibroblasts and that physiological antioxidants like 3'.-toeopherol, Bcarotene, ascorbic-and uric acid were able to inhibit these NO~-induced genetoxic effects. Possibly the denitrosation pathway may contribute to the careinogenicity of N-nitroso compounds. Quite probably NO2 has some relevance for the observed lipid peroxidation induced by some Nnitrosamines.

body_text.text: To investigate further the significance of NO and its oxidation product NO2 with respect to possible genetoxic effects, we studied SIN-I which is the active metabolite of molsidomine, a drug against angina pectoris. As NO is generated from S1N-I the denitrosation reaction of N-nitrosamines could be simulated in metabolic inactive V 79 cells. Therefore V 79 cells were treated with millimolar concentrations of SIN-I and micromolar concentrations of various antioxidative vitamins for different hours. The rate of SSBs was measured by the alkaline elution assay, the amount of DNA by a fluorimetric assay, We found considerable amounts of SSBs by treating V 79 cells with e.g. 3 rnM SIN-I for 12 hours. These SSBs were effectively inhibited by addition of e.g. 100 pM ascorbie acid. The antioxidative vitamin ~,-tocopharol did not inhibit SIN-l-induced SSBs. The fact that SIN-I induced SSBs in V 79 ceils, which were inhibited by aseorbic acid supports the hypothesis that NO~ and/or other radicals are involved in the SIN-1 dependent generation of genetoxie effects. Methylene chloride (CH2Cl 2) has been classified by the European Communities as a compound suspect of carcinogenic activity (R40). A glutathionedependent metabolic pathway leads to the formation of formaldehyde (HCHO). In earlier experiments with methyl chloride (CH3C1), we could ascribe the resulting DNA-damage due to the action of HCHO, an intermediate formed in CH3CI metabolism which may react with nucleic acids and protein.

Inhalation of TDI vapours is associated with immediate type hypersensitivity, direct toxic effects and allergic alveolitis. TDI is known to induce chromosome aberrations, base-pair substitution and frameshift mutation after metabolic activation.

body_text.text: The immediate effect of toluene diisocyanate (TDI) upon genomic DNA of sheep and rabbit white blood cells has been investigated. The results of FPLC indicate that TDI induces DNA double-strand breaks in sheep white blood cells. Following denaturation of TDI treated DNA, the results demonstrated that at least one DNA fragment, representing about 10 -20% of total DNA, is cross-linked by TDI or TDI metabolites. About 39% more of double-stranded structures are reconstituted in DNA extracted from sheep white blood cells three hours after incubation with TDI.

Further studies with prednisone have been conducted to correlate these results with the phenomenon of apoptosis. The in vitro results show that TDI can induce degradation of mitochondrial DNA and large DNA fragments caused by apoptosis to small DNA fragments.

Heidemann** Sennosides and rhein did not increase the number of revertants in five Salmonella typhimurium strains when tested up to 5000 gg/plate in the presence and absence of metabolic activation. Sennosides and rhein were tested for their ability to induce mutations at the thymidine-kinase (TK +/') locus of mouse lymphoma L 5178 Y cells both in the presence and absence of $9 mix. Up to the highest concentrations tested, there were no biological significant increases in mutation frequencies with sennosides or rhein. The chromosomal aberration test was carried out with cultured Chinese hamster ovary cells (CHO). From the results, there was no evidence for a clastogenic activity of sennosides and rhein either in the presence or absence of metabolic activation. The micronucleus assay was performed in mice at oral dose levels of 100, 500 and 2,500 mg/kg (sennosides) or 1,500 mg/kg (rhein). The test compounds did not increase the number of micronucleated polychromatic erythrocytes. These results suggest that sennosides and rhein have no mutagenic potential in vitro and in vivo. is the most widely used antituberculosis drug. The hepatic toxicity of INH was noted early and there are reports of increased risk of liver reaction when INH-treatment is combined with rifampicin, another antituberberculosis drug, or with alcohol consumption. Mutagenic activity of INH was found in the salmonella-mutagenicity-assay which has been proposed due to its metabolic conversion into hydrazine, a well-known microbial mutagen. Rifampicin and ethanol are known to be chronic inducers of naicrosomal enzymes. In this study investigations on the interaction of INH, rifampicin and ethanol were performed in order to detect if induction of microsomal enzynaes may increase the mutagenicity of INH. Mice were pretreated orally with 1NH (66 mg/kg b.w.), rifampicin (88 mg/kg b.w. in drinking water ad lib) or ethanol (10 % w.v.) alone, or with a combination of the substances mentioned above. The effect of pretreatment was tested on induction of microsomal enzymes (Burke et.al., Biochem. Pharmacol.: 34, 3337, 1985) and on mutagenicity in the salmonella-mammalian microsome assay (Ames-test) according to Maron and Ames 1983 (Mut. Res.: 113, 173) . Liver-S9 of differentIy pretreated animals was used as metabolizing systena and was tested on its enzyme activity. The data demonstrate that the oxidative metabolisna of INH can be induced by pretreatment with INH and rifampicin and/or ethanol and is increased especially by pretreatment of female animals with ]NH, rifampicin and ethanol. In the Ames-test INH demonstrated a slight mutagenic activity with TA 1535, no nautagenicity was found with TA 100 and TA 98 tester strain of salmonella. However, compared to control mouse liver-S9, the metabolic activatioo mediated by pretreated mouse liver-S9 caused neither enhancement nor reduction of the response. The results postulate that concomitant treatment with rifanapicin or alcohol consumption do not increase the mutagenic effect of INH. In a previous study, it was shown that 2-naethylpropene (isobutene), a gaseous compound widely used for the production of rubber chemicals, plastics, adhesives, sealing compounds, fuel additives and antioxidants, is metabolized to the epoxide 2-methyl-1,2-epoxypropane. Furthermore, the mutugenic activity of 2-naethylpropene and its naetubolite was tested in several systems. In contrast to the parent compound, for which the results were negative, the epoxide showed amutagenic effect in the Ames test.

body_text.text: In the experiments presented here, the nautagenicity ofthesetwo compounds was tested in the ,,in vitro" micrunueleus test using human lymphocytes. Cultures (5nal), were prepared in gastight test flasks coutaining4 ral medium (Ham F10 with Hepes buffer), 0,8 ml foetal calf serum, 0.1 nal phytohaemagglutiuine and 0.4 nal whole blood. 2-Methylpropene and its epoxide were injected with a gaslight syringe in different concentrations. Since 2-naethylpropene is practically insoluble in water, each concentration was tested in double -once by shaking the cultures to maximize exposure to the cells, and once without shaking. After incubation at 37°C for 44 h, cytoeholasine B was added to a final concentration of 61.11/ml, and after 72 h the cultures were harvested. The lymphocytes were isolated by density centfifugation with Ficoll-Paque and subjected to hypotonic treatment 0tPMl:water, 1:3). The sample was again centril~gated and the pellet was applied to slides as spots. The slides were subsequently fixed in 100 % naethanol for 10 nfin and stained with 5 % Gienasa. 1000 binucleate cells were counted at a magnification of 1000. The test results show that 2-methylpropene induced no naicronuclei in contrast to its epoxide 2-methyl-1,2-epoxypropane. This epoxide shows an approximate dose response in the frequency of micronuclei, Shaking of the cultures had ilo influence on the mutagenic effects, neither for 2-naethylpropene nor for its epoxide. The toxicity test parameters concerning the chick embryo comprise, generally, lethality, developmental retardation, teratogenicity, hematological criteria and organ histopathology (see, e.g., Kemper and Luepke, Fd. Chem.Toxic. 24, 647-648, 1986) . Additionally, some biochemical and physico-chemical methods may provide an excellent means in screening for nucleotoxicity. Therefore, some DNA and/or chromatin interactive agents were tested in vitro and/or in vivo by scheduled (SDS) and unscheduled (UDS) DNA synthesis, RNA synthesis, viscometry of alkaline cell lysates and nucleoid sedimentation with freshly isolated liver and brain cells from the 15th day old chick embryo. As compared to manunalian cells, the physico-chemical tests reveal a high spontaneous -possibly apoptotic -rate of DNA strand breakage in the embryonic cells which is biochemically confirmed by the high basic activity of some DNA repair enzymes and/or phenomena, such as poly(ADP-ribose)polymerase and hydroxyurea resistant DNA synthesis. Because of the high spontaneous DNA fragmentation in primary cultures of chick embryo cells some DNA strand breaking agents may be detected with lower sensitivity than in mammalian cells. An additional disadvantage is the innate inability to metabolize various indirectly acting agents. Apart from this, similar dose-effect relationships were obtained with directly acting genotoxic agents in chicken embryo and rat cells. The gp 80 giycoprotein complex is the canine homolog of the rat TRPM-2 (Testosteron-repressed message-2), the htmaan Apolipoprotein J and complement lysis inhibitor (CLI). There is direct evidence from avian and circumstantial evidence from mammalian systems that the gp 80 gene is regulated by oneogene products. In quail neuroretinal cells gp 80 expression is enhanced after transfeetion with Rous Sarcoma Virus. In mammalians gp 80 is induced during apoptosis in the regressing prostate of the rat after castration and in rat kidney after ureter obstruction. In both cases the expression of c-myc is increased. We have shown, that gp 80 mRNA is enhanced in human kidney clear cell tumors and in rat phaeochromocytoma cells PCI2 during NGF induced differentiation, which is known to be mediated by the action of ras oncogene. We have isolated a mouse genomie done carrying 10 kbp of 5"-ftanking sequences, the 5"-untranslated region and most of the coding part of the gp 80 gene. We will use these sequences for mobility shift assays, footprinting experiments and transfection experiments with reporter genes in suitable acceptur cells, such as PC12 and Rat-1 cells expressing the e-myc gene under the control of a regulatable promotor, to characterize the DNA elements involved in gp 80 regulation. Cellular oncogenes (protooncogenes) are involved in growth and differentiation of cells. Protooncogenes of the raf-family are located in the cytoplasm and mediate signal transfer between membrane bound receptors and nuclear effectors. An altered expression has been found in tumors and transformed ceils. We studied the expression of c-raf in early stages of chemically induced rat liver tumorigenesis using juvenile female or adult male Sprague-Dawley (SD) rats: After initiation with diethylnitrosamine, for promotion polychlorinated biphenyls (PCBs) or phenobarbital (PB) was applied to female rats, to males PCBs only. The incidence of preneoplastic loci was evaluated histochemically by demonstrating deficiency in adenosine-5'-triphosphatase (ATPase) and emergence of gammagiutamyltranspeptidase (GGTase). C-raf expression was measured biocherrdcally in /iver tissue containing preneoplastic foci and in isolated hyperplastic nodules up to 36 weeks. In female rats foci numbers amounted to 60-70/cm 2 liver section with both promoters and both histochernical markers. In male SD rats foci numbers reached about 20-40/cm 2 with both markers and with PCBs as promoting agent. Foci area developed more rapidly in female rats. In female rats c-raf expression foil-owed generally the time course of foei development and was highest in large nodules (> 4 mm in diameter) with up to 3-fold in PB-treated and 10-fold-in PCB-treated animals compared to untreated controls. In male rats craf expression was marginal and nodule incidence was neglectibly low.

body_text.text: GSF -llnstitut ftir Toxikologie, 8042 Neuherberg GSF -2Abteilung ffir Zellchemie, 8042 Neuherberg Overexpression of p-glycoprotein encoded by fine mdrl class of genes confers multidrug resistance towards a variety of cytotoxic drugs since p-glycoprotein functions as an energy dependent efflux pump of amphipathic polycyclic compounds. In hepatocytes which exhibit physiologically high expression of p-glycoprotein, the protein is located in cytoplasmic membranes exposed to biliary canaliculi indicating its significance as an excretion system for toxic exogenous or endogenous substances into the bile. In order to investigate a possible influence of tumor promoters such as phenobarbital or of hepatotrophlc growth factors such as epidermal growth factor (EGF)or transforming growth factor-a (TGF-a) on p-glycoprotein expression, primary murine hepatocytes isolated by collagenase perfusion and maintained in serum-free culture medium were incubated with EGF {10 pM-10 nM) or 1.5 mM phenobarbital for up to 3 days. Subsequently, p-glycoprotein expression was determined by Western blot analysis of cytoplasmic membrane fractions utilizing enhanced luminescence detection. Treatment of murine hepatocytes with EGF had no significant effect on p-glycoprotein levels although partial hepatectomy is known to induce mRNA expression in rats and the TGF-a/EGF receptor is thought to play a role in mediation of liver regeneration following partial hepatectomy. However, culture of hepatocytes led to a decrease in detectable p-glycoprotein indicating that pglycoprotein expression might act as a marker of differentiated hepatocyte function. , 1929, 1989) . Hepatocytes isolated from carcinogen-treated rats immediately after termination of PB-promotion showed a dye coupling of only about 50%. Putative preneoplastic hepatocytes in these cultures were visualized by indirect immunofluorescence using anti-z-glutamyltranspeptidase (r-GT) antibodies. Dye coupling in r-GT-positive hepatocytes was significantly lower amounting to only 20%. Due to their low capacity to communicate, preneoplastic liver cells may escape from the growth control of surrounding normal cells. Enzyme-altered putative preneoplastic liver foci were induced in Wistar rats by application of diethylnitrosamine (10 mg/kg/day) for 5 days, followed by treatment with 2,3,7,8-tetrachlorodibenzo-p-dioxin (TCDD; 100 ng/kg/day) or 1,2,3,4,6,7,8-heptachlorodibenzo-p-dioxin (HCDD; 5/zg/kg/day) for up to 17 weeks. Groups of animals were killed 5, 9, 13, or 17 weeks after start of promoter treatment. For evaluation of DNA synthesis, 5-bromo-2'deoxyuridine (BrdU) was administered 24 hours prior to sacrifice. While TCDD concentrations in livers reached a steady state after 9-13 weeks of treatment, HCDD concentrations increased steadily. Quantitation of adenosine-triphosphatase-deficient liver foci revealed that the number and volume fraction were significantly increased in TCDD and HCDD-treated rats, indicating comparable promoting activity. Using a double-labeling technique, glutathione-transferase (GST)-P-positive liver cells were found to show an approximately 10-fold higher labeling index (LI) than normal cells at all periods of investigation. When examining the time course of DNA synthesis, a time dependent decrease of BrdU-labeling was found in loci of all treatment groups. In TCDD-treated rats, the initially high rate of proliferation appeared to persist for a greater length of time. Assignment of liver loci into 4 size classes revealed that after 5 weeks of promoter treatment foci in the stablest size class had a very high LI, whereas foci in larger size classes had moderate to low Lls. At subsequent time points, Lls of foci in the smallest size class decreased progressively. LIs in the larger size classes varied considerably without obvious correlation between LI, size of the lesions or time point of investigation, indicating heterogeneity in the growth behaviour of liver lesions. Overall, HCDD had only marginal effects on LIs, while TCDD seemed to slightly enhance the LI of liver foci. Adenosine shows a multiplicity of actions which in regard to the systemic circulation are negative chronotropic, negative dromotropic, negative inotropic and vasodilator effects. Metabolically stable, potent and highly selective A 1 and A 2 adenosine receptor agonists and antagonists provide useful pharmacological tools in separating different receptor responses in vivo. The quantitative in vivo characterization of the relationship between pharmaeokinetics and pharmacodyuamics using an appropriate, clinically relevant pharmacodynamic variable then allows evaluation of the possible role of purinurgie drugs for ultimate use in man. The selective adenosine agonist ~-Cyclopentyladenosine (CPA) and antagonist Cyclopentyltheophylline (CPT) have proved to be valuable tools in the characterization of the A1 adenosine receptor subtype in vivo in rats. The pharmacokinetic and pharmacodyaamic interaction between CPA and CPT was quantified by standard pharmacokinetic parameters, a reduction in heart rate and a decrease in mean arterial blood pressure. Four groups of eight rats each received 200 ,ug/kg of CPA intravenously in 5 minutes at a steady-state infusion of CPT at a rate of 0, 57, 114 and 228 ,ug/kg/h, respectively. The blood concentration -heart rate relationships of CPA during the three different CPT steady-state concentrations were derived from each animal. A two-exponential equation was used to quantitatively describe the blood concentration -time profiles of CPA. The pharmacokinetics of CPA did not change in the presence of CPT. Similar pharmacokinetie parameter estimates of CPA were obtained as compared to control administration with mean half-lives of 6.4 + 0.23, 5.9 + 0.42, 7.0 ± 0.20 and 7.1 ± 0.26 rain and mean volumes of distribution of 269 + 16, 264 ± 6, 268 -+ 6 and 314 ± 26 ml/kg with raising CPT steady-state concentration. The concentration -heart rate relationship of CPA was quantitatively characterized fitting the sigmoid Era~x model to individual data. At the steady-state concentrations investigated CPT showed no intrinsic efficacy with respect to heart rate. The mean baseline heart rate measurements E 0 and mean maximal effect values Ema x of CPA were comparable among the four groups. CPT did not influence the shape of the concentration effect profiles of CPA as well. However, the three different CPT steadystate concentrations caused the pharmacodynamic parameter estimate ECs0 of heart rate to increase from 2 ± 0.7, 15 -+ 2.0, 38 -+ 8.6 upto 91 -+ 12 ng/ml with increasing antagonist concentration (0, 14 ± 1, 32 -+ 1, 59 ± 5 ng/ml, respectively). Simultaneous pharmacoklnefic -pharmacodynumic modelling allowed estimation of the pharmacodynamic parameters for CPT as well. The apparent parallel shift in the concentration -heart rate relationships of CPA with increasing CPT eoneentratian indicates a competitive agonist-antagonist interaction at the A 1 adenosine receptor subtype in vivo in rats.

body_text.text: Center for Bit-Pharmaceutical Sciences, University of Leiden, P.O.Box 9503, NL 2300 RA, The Netherlands Glimepiride is a new hypoglycaemic agent of the sulfony~urea group. Its main biotransformation products are the metabolites M1 (hydroxyglimepiride) and M2 (carboxyglimepidde). The aim of the study was to investigate the pharmacokinetics of a 1.5 mg dose of M1 given intravenously. Pharmacodynamics were compared to placebo. Twelve healthy males, mean age 26 years (22 -33) and mean weight 75 kg (69 -85) received 1.5 mg M1 or 0.9 % NaC} in a randomized cross-over design as i.v. injection. On the days before dosing, food and fluid intake were standardized. On the tdal days no food was permitted until 10 h after medication. Concentrations of M1 and M2 in serum and urine (HPLC), glucose, insulin and C-peptide in serum were determined.

body_text.section: Relationships between pharmacokinetics and changes of the ECG in healthy volunteers for the antiarrhythmic agent tiracizin

body_text.text: Tiracizin (Bonnecor ~, AWE) GmbH Dresden) is a newly developed antiarrhythmic drug used predominately in the treatment of ventricular and supraventricular tachycardias. Within the comprehensive pharmacokinetic characterization of tiracizin and three of its metabolites the serum concentration -effect relationships were investigated regarding changes of the ECG of 8 healthy volunteers, Investigations were carried out after single oral administration of 50, 100, 200 mg and during steady state (50 rag, b.i.d.), respectively, Heart rate increased in a dose dependent manner. Average peak rate was measured 3 h after drug administration, correspondir~g to tmax of the main metabolite. Qre remained unchanged. However, there were dose dependent prolongations of PQ and QRS. These effects culminated at tmax of the parent compound (1 h after dosing). For tiracizin concentrations above 80 ng/ml the log concentration-effect curves displayed a linear increase without reaching any plateau within the concentration range observed. For this reason enhanced conduction defects might not be excluded after repeated administration of higher doses. In some volunteers AV block I* and pattern of bandle branch block could be observed temporarily after single administration of 200 mg tiracizin, Taking into account the tiracizin-related extensions of PQ and QRS as well as the extensive hepatic metabolism of this drug (first pass effect 60-70 %), tiracizin is suspected for inducing conductivity disorders after doses mentoined above in patients with decreased hepatic blood flow (i.e. heart failure; liver disease, especially if it is complicated by shunting). x 1005 is an acidic quinoline type inhibitor of 5-1ipexigenase with high oral activity in different species and currendy in phase-II of clinical development. Three issues were investigated: 1. The relative bioavailability of a tablet with 250 mg BAY x 1005 vs. an oral solution as reference (randomized cross-over with 12 male volunteers). 2.The in-fluence of an antacid (Maalox®) on the kinetics of BAY x 1005 (2x250 mg as tablet, randomized cross over with 8 volunteers). 3. The possible effect of the simultaneous intake of an american breakfast on the kinetics (cross-over, 4 volunteers, 2x250 mg ). BAY x 1005 was analyzed by HPLC with heart-cut column switching, separation in a narrow-bore RP-18-cohilnn and UV-detection at 305 nm. The method shows a high precision and accuracy of below 5% (calculated as r.s.d, and deviation from conventional true value, resp.). The limit of quantification was 3 ng/ml. Relative bioavailability of the tablet is about 100% with a distinct higher Cmax and more rapid absorption after administration as solution. The slight antacid interaction (33% increase in Cmax) may be caused by a lowering of the gastric pH and thereby increased solubility of BAY x 1005. The strong food effect on Cmax is interpreted in terms of an increase of the in-rive solubility, too. In all studies BAY x 1005 was well tolerated. Oral low dose aspirin has been used for the prevention of vascular occlusion and reocclusion due to its selective, presystemic effect on platelet cyclooxygenase (COX) in the portal circulation. As this treatment takes 3 -5 days to become effective, patients with unstable angina or on thrombolysis have been given high oral or intravenous loading doses to achieve a rapid onset of platelet inhibition, thus suppressing the favourable vascular effects of prostacyclin and risking higher rates of untoward effects. Therefore we have developed a regimen for a single intravenous low dose of aspirin (LDA, 50 rng, 60 min) and compared its effects on platelet aggregation and prostanoid formation with high dose aspirin (HDA, 500 mg i.v.) and placebo in 10 healthy male volunteers. The infusion rate for LDA was adjusted to previously determined venous blood flow rates in order to avoid systemic inhibitory plasma levels of aspirin in the systemic Circulation by means of dilution in the venous circulation; HDA was infused within the same time period. The urinary metabolites of TXA2 (2,3Ktinor-TXB2), prostacyclin (2,3-dinor-6-keto-PGPI~), and urinary PGE2 were determined by GC-MS/MS. Urinary PGE2 is solely derived from the kidney and was taken as an index of systemic COX activity. Platelet aggregation was similarly inhibited by LDA and HDA by more than 85% at 30 rain and remained suppressed for 24 h. Platelet TXA2 synthesis was maximally inhibited at 60 rain after LDA (-93.8%); it was below detection limit at 10 rain after HDA. Urinary 2,3dinor-TXB2 was equally suppressed by HDA (-83.2%) and LDA (-67.4%; n.s.). The urinary excretion of 2,3-dinor-6-keto:PGFla and of PGE2 was also markedly decreased by 79.2% and 63.5%, respectively, after HDA, whereas LDA suppressed 2,3dinor-6-keto-PGFla excretion significantly less (-30.3%; p<0,02) , and had no inhibitory effect on PGE2 excretion. The ratio of 2,3-dinor-6-keto-PGFla / 2,3-dinor-TXB2 was unaffected by HDA or placebo (from 1.0 to 1.2 and 1.1, respectively), but was markedly increased after LDA (to 2.1). These data show that the clinical pharmacological adjustment of LDA infusion rates may beneficially influence its effects on platelet aggregation and TXA2synthesis while sparing systemic COX activity (as detemined by urinary PGE2). However, a slight inhibition of urinary 2,3-dinor-6-keto-PGFlc~ excretion seems to be an unavoidable consequence of platelet COX inhibition by aspirin, and is probably due to the inhibited transfer of platelet-derived endoperoxides to the endothelium, thus depriving it of one of its sources for prostacyclin synthesis. Dynamic light evoked pupillometry has proved to be a reliable method to evaluate pharmacodynamic effects of CNS active drugs. To investigate a possible correlation between the route of administration and the pharmacodynamic effect of the neuroleptic drug chlorprothixen a fourfold crossover tdal was carried out. 3 different oral galenical formulations of chlorprothixen (film coated tablet, suspension, aequous solution) were applied in dosages of 100 mg each to 8 healthy male volunteers and compared to 100 mg of the i.v. formulation. Pupil diameter was determined using noninvasive dynamic light evoked pupillometry (light stimulus with intensity of 22 cd/qm, duration of 0.1 s). Sedes of 10 repeated single measurements (duration 3 s, interval 30 s) were performed in supine position, before and 1, 2, 3, 4, 5, 6, 8, 10, 24 and 48 h after drug administration. Initial, minimal and final diameter as well as reflex amplitude and time to minimal diameter were recorded and used for further evaluation. Chlorprothixen serum concentrations were determined at the above mentioned time points. Results: 2 x 4 fold ANOVA indicates (p<0.01) that all four formulations can be differentiated on the basis of reflex amplitude, initial, minimal and final diameter, the reflex amplitude (p<0.001) appearing to be the most sensitive indicator. Furthermore, relationship between plasma levels and mathematically transformed reflex amplitude was analyzed. Up to a concentration of ~10pg/L changes the of pupil diameter corresponds to the course of plasma levels. Conclusions: Our results indicate that pupillometry is a suitable method to characterize the different formulations of chlorprothixen and may lead to an estimation of plasma levels within a limited range. The non-selective muscarinic ag nists acetylcholine (ACh) and methacholine {MCh) are known to induce vasodilatafion in the forearm vascular bed. At least part of this response apparently seems to be dependent on the release of nitric oxide (NO). Animal experiments indicate the involvement of the M3-receptor in endotheliumdependent relaxation of vascular smooth muscle. To further assess the vasodilatation induced by ACh and MCh in the forearm of normotensive volunteers (n=10), we infused ACh (dose range 1 -1000 ng/kg/min) in the presence of saline, and MCh (dose range 0.1 -1000 ng/kg/min) in the presence of saline, the non-selecfive muscarinic antagonist atropine (dose range 0.6-6 ng/kg/min) or Ms-receptor selective pirenzepine (dose range 0.8 -800 ng/kg/min), and the gyanylate-cyclase and NO-scavenger methylene blue (1000 ng/kg/min), using automated R-wave triggered venous occlusion plethysmography. By calculating the plasmaconcentrafions of the infused compounds, we were able to obtain ECso-Values and perform 'Schild analysis'. ACh and MCh both caused dose-dependent vasodilatation (ECso-Values of 1.34 5:0.62 ,uM and 64.8 + 13.5 riM, respectively). The dose-response curve (DRC) of MCh was shifted to the right by both atropine and pirenzepine (apparent pA2-values of 7.92 5:0.24 and 6.70 5: 0.04, respectively; slopes not different from unity). Methylene blue did not affect the DRC of MCh. The apparent 20-fold higher potency of MCh compared to ACh, can be explained by the rapid degradation of ACh in the plasma. The pA2-value of pirenzepine is comparable to values reported by in vitro experiments. The apparent pA2-value of atropine is relatively low compared to literature. This can be explained by the fact that atropine is known to require a long time to reach a steadystate equilibrium. Unlike our previous finding that methylene blue potentiates ACh-induced vasodilatation in the forearm, methylene blue did not influence the vasodilatation to MCh. The human forearm is a well established model for resistance vessels. The present technique enables us to perform muscsrinic receptor characterization using different competitive antagonists in the vascular bed of the human forearm. The antiarrhythmic drug propafenone (2'[2 hydroxy-3(propylamino)propoxy]-3phenylpropiophenone) is subject to extensive and variable metabolism in man. Variability is mainly introduced by genetically polymorphic, CYP2D6 mediated 5-hydroxylation, which is absent in 7% of a Caucasian population. This subset of patients (poor metabolisers; PM) has a higher incidence of side effects as compared to extensive metabolisers (EM) and hence knowledge of phenotype would be desirable. Conventional phenotyping during therapy is impossible, since propafenone is a strong competitive inhibitor of metabolism of probe drugs such as sparteine. While EM excret most of propafenone as gincuronide of 5hydroxypropafenone, PM eliminate propafenone by formation of glucuronide of parent compound. Thus determining the excretion of propafenone glucuronide (PPFG) in urine should allow an assignment of phenotype.

body_text.text: We therefore developed a method to phenotype patients during chronic therapy using the urinary excretion of PPFG. PPFG was quantified by HPLC using propafenone glucuronide-O-methyloxime as internal standard. Urinary excretion of PPFG was determined in eleven patients (3 female, 8 male; age 61 5: 8.4) during dosage interval and related to the metabolic ratio (MR) of sparteine (ratio of sparteine and the hydroxy metabolites in the 8 hour urine after administration of 100 mg of sparteine), which had been determined before initiation of therapy. Total excretion of PPFG ranged from 8 to 117 mg (3.6 to 51.5 % of dose) and was correlated to the MR of sparteine (r=0.95, P< 0.001).
body_text.section: Results

body_text.text: In conclusion, urinary excretion of propafenone glucuronides reflects sparteine phenotype and may be useful for phenotype assignment during propafenone therapy. Clinical therapy with prostacyclin or its chemically stable analogs is limited by the dose-dependent occurrence of unwanted drug effects, like hypotension, flush, headache and diarrhea. Therefore, in order to maintain the platelet antiaggregatory effect but to avoid these unwanted drug effects we studied the augmentation of platelet inhibitory effects of iloprost by acetylsalicylic acid (ASA). In a placebo controlled, randomized trial ASA (0, 10, 30, 100 or 300 mg/d) was administered to five groups of eight volunteers each for seven consecutive days. On day eight, exactly one hour after the intake of the last dose of ASA, intravenous infusion of iloprost was initiated with increasing doses of 0.5, 1 and 2 ng/kg/min for one hour each. Blood was withdrawn on day 1, day 4 and day 8 before and after the ASA intake and after 60 minutes of each iloprost infusion dose. Serum thromboxane was dosedependently reduced by ASA for 48, 92, 98 and 99% of control following intake of 10, 30, 100 and 300 mg of ASA. Collagen induced platelet aggregation was reduced by 62% following intake of placebo and infusion of iloprost at 2 ng/kg/min. When the volunteers were on ASA, already 10 mg ASA/day were sufficient to augment the inhibitory potency of iloprost, resulting in a 57% inhibition during infusion of 0.5 ng/kg/min of iloprost. Thus, the platelet inhibitory potency of iloprost was significantly enhanced already by very low doses of ASA, allowing for an effective platelet inhibitor therapy with low iloprost infusion rates with a low rate of unwanted drug effects.
